timeline.bodyText: RuntimeException might not be the best exception to be wrapped with. The reason I didn't use IOException is because I figured not all exceptions thrown on connection are retryable, but is that true?
timeline.author: zoewangg

replies.bodyText: Wouldn't we want IOExceptions to stay IOExceptions? Any reason we need to re-wrap here?
replies.author: millems

replies.bodyText: The reason I re-wrap it here is to provide more descriptive message on the exception. Currently, it's not very clear why the request fails.
replies.author: zoewangg

replies.bodyText: Wouldn't this make currently-retried exceptions not be retried? Should we make it an IOException if the wrapped is an IOException?
replies.author: millems

replies.bodyText:
I thought our default retry policy would check if the root cause of the exception is assignable from IOException, but turns out it would only check one level down.

  
    
      aws-sdk-java-v2/core/sdk-core/src/main/java/software/amazon/awssdk/core/retry/conditions/RetryOnExceptionsCondition.java
    
    
        Lines 59 to 62
      in
      138def2
    
    
    
    

        
          
           Predicate<Class<? extends Exception>> hasRetrableCause = 
        

        
          
               ex -> exception.getCause() != null && ex.isAssignableFrom(exception.getCause().getClass()); 
        

        
          
            
        

        
          
           return exceptionsToRetryOn.stream().anyMatch(isRetryableException.or(hasRetrableCause)); 
        
    
  


I'll make it an IOException if the wrapped is an IOException
replies.author: zoewangg

replies.bodyText: Or we could update the retry policy to check down the entire chain? That would probably be better.
replies.author: millems

replies.bodyText: +1. I'll create a backlog item for it. I think it'd still be nice to wrap IOException with an IOException here to make it clear this is a transient retryable I/O related error.
replies.author: zoewangg

timeline.bodyText: Do we still need the IN_USE checks in the handler if we are removing it?
timeline.author: millems

replies.bodyText: Hmm, good point. I'll change it to only add it once when the channel is created and not removing it.
replies.author: zoewangg

replies.bodyText: Reverted this change. Now we only attach UnusedChannelExceptionHandler to h1 channels once they are created
replies.author: zoewangg

timeline.bodyText: This seems super fragile. Can we just have a handler at the end of every pipeline that closes on exception?
timeline.author: millems

replies.bodyText: The connection could get closed before any handler is attached to stream channels and there would be nothing catching the exception. I found out this issue in my testing where I set a very low pingPeriod.
replies.author: zoewangg

replies.bodyText: Can we have a handler attached to the end of every channel as soon as it is created, before it is even connected, that calls close() when an exception is fired on the channel, assuming nothing else closed the channel already?
replies.author: millems

replies.bodyText: Updated to attach UnusedChannelExceptionHandler to the stream channels once they are created and that should take care of it.
replies.author: zoewangg

timeline.bodyText: What happens when an exception is fired on a parent H2 channel after this change?
timeline.author: millems

replies.author: zoewangg

timeline.bodyText: minor: instanceof here is more concise
timeline.author: dagnir

timeline.message: Update UnusedExceptionHandler to a per-request handler. Wrapps a connection thrown from a connection with more information before delivering to stream channels.
Fix the issue where the publisher signals onComplete if the stream is closed as a result of outbound of GOAWAY.
